submission.title: Chromium Reputation Provider Framework: A Decentralized Reputation Layer for the Web
submission.overview: This draft proposal from the Chromium team outlines a browser-native framework enabling users to install, manage, and utilize multiple independent reputation providers. It envisions a decentralized ecosystem for reputational signals, facilitating both positive and negative assessments of websites and content. This approach prioritizes user choice, system resilience, and reputational pluralism over centralized moderation or gatekeeping by browser vendors. It aims to replicate the utility of walled-garden trust systems (e.g., Amazon reviews) while retaining the open and user-controlled nature of the web. The framework proposes multiple technical mechanisms for secure and privacy-respecting attestations, enabling scalable and nuanced integration of reputational data into browsing experiences. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

directly_addressed_dps.summary: Empowers users to choose, combine, and remove reputation providers according to their preferences, without vendor interference.

directly_addressed_dps.dp: DP3 - Adaptive Governance Supporting an Exponentially Growing Community
directly_addressed_dps.summary: Supports heterogeneous, user-accountable reputation providers rather than central authorities.
Ensures privacy by default with user-controlled data sharing mechanisms.
Enables trusted transactions through reputation-enhanced validation.
Offers a unified and extensible provider integration interface.
Supports diverse, pluralistic reputation networks for community co-existence.
Allows AI-enhanced reputation to be modular, uninstallable, and transparent.
Promotes trust through visible signals, provider disclosure, and user control.
Uses cryptographic attestations for data integrity and source verification.
Allows users to report inconsistencies and improve reputational signals.
Enables bottom-up formation of trust networks without institutional gatekeeping.

clarifications_and_extensions.dp: DP3 – Adaptive Governance Supporting an Exponentially Growing Community
clarifications_and_extensions.title: User-Curated Reputation Stacks
clarifications_and_extensions.clarification: Adaptive governance is implemented through dynamic user-curated reputation stacks rather than centralized governance structures.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Supports flexibility and user-defined networks of trust without central bottlenecks.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Zero-Knowledge Privacy Methods
clarifications_and_extensions.extension: Incorporates zero-knowledge methods like anonymizing proxies and hash-prefix lookups to preserve user privacy.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Enables personalization and trust without surveillance-based profiling.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Decentralized Trust Signal Interpretation
clarifications_and_extensions.clarification: Trust signals are transparent, but interpretation is decentralized across pluralistic providers.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Empowers users to adjudicate conflicting views, maintaining subjectivity and choice.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Granular Content Provenance Tracking
clarifications_and_extensions.extension: Adds signed attestations per subresource/media to track decentralized content origin and trust.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Builds layered provenance across granular web elements.

clarifications_and_extensions.title: Bottom-Up Trust Network Formation
clarifications_and_extensions.clarification: No curation or gatekeeping—trust networks arise through opt-in community choice, not institutional approval.
clarifications_and_extensions.why_it_matters: Prevents co-optation of the trust layer by dominant entities.
